citation.article-title: Calderobacterium hydrogenophilum nov. gen., nov. sp., an extreme thermophilic bacterium and its hydrogenase activity.

p.s: Calderobacterium (from caldera (Portugese for "cauldron") used by A. Humboldt to describe volcanic structures; bacterium, rod; rod growing in calderas)
The genus consists of extremely thermophilic, gram-negative, rod-shaped bacteria, growing in hot gas springs.
They are colorless, nonmotile, nonspore-forming, and obligately autotrophic.
The G + C content is about 40 mol %.
It differs from the sole genus of gram-negative, extremely thermophilic bacteria Thermus in the absence of pigment, G + C content, and ability to oxidize hydrogen.
